title: Political Change

description: How anonymous credible commitments enable political dissent in authoritarian regimes by allowing citizens to coordinate without fear.
content:
Citizens in an authoritarian regime oppose the government but won't speak out unless they know the majority shares their views. Fear of being the only dissenter keeps everyone silent.

The Silence Problem

In authoritarian regimes, expressing dissent is dangerous. Individuals who speak out alone face severe consequences, while the regime benefits from the perception that opposition is minimal. This creates a coordination trap where everyone wants change but no one acts.

Breaking the Silence

Anonymous credible commitments allow citizens to express their opposition privately, committing to public action only when enough others have also committed. A student might set their threshold at 10,000 commitments, while a journalist might need 50,000. When the threshold is reached, all committed individuals are revealed together.

Safety in Numbers

This approach provides the safety in numbers that makes political change possible. Citizens can coordinate their opposition without exposing themselves to individual risk, transforming silent discontent into visible collective action.
